awd_titl_txt: Mapping subduction-induced Mantle Flow Underneath North/Central America and Europe
awd_abstract_narration:
Mapping mantle flow induced by the descending oceanic lithosphere has important implications for understanding subduction processes. Two fundamental types of subduction-induced mantle flows have been suggested based on laboratory experiments, mantle flow computer simulations and shear wave splitting measurements. However, to date, the behaviors of these flow modes at different depths in an actual subduction environment remain elusive. In this project, the PI proposes to characterize mantle flow circulation patterns for five active convergent margins in North/Central America and Europe: the Middle America, Caribbean, Cascadia, Calabria and Hellenic. Analyzing these results will improve our understanding of the thermal and chemical evolution of subduction systems. In addition, Central America, Cascadia and the Mediterranean are among the most seismologically active regions in the world. With the new 3-D tomographic models, the team will numerically simulate Earth's responses associated with a number of past and future large magnitude earthquakes in these regions, which may provide valuable information about earthquake hazards in densely populated regions. This project will advance the development of the University of Texas, Dallas Seismic Imaging Laboratory by supporting an early career PI and one Ph.D. graduate student. Results from this project will be disseminated via peer-reviewed publications and presentations at national/international meetings. 

With the support of this project, the PI's team will use full waveform inversion to constrain 3-D azimuthal anisotropy structures for five subduction systems in North/Central America and Europe. This inversion strategy offers a unified framework to simultaneously constrain multiple seismic parameters, and enables the team to better extract quantitative information about Earth materials by fitting recorded waveforms with full-wavefield modeling results. The PI plans to combine three-component body and surface waves to simultaneously constrain wavespeeds and azimuthal anisotropy from the crust down to the transition zone. By examining correlations between wavespeed anomalies and anisotropic fabrics, the PI wants to address the following three fundamental questions: (1) How are the poloidal- and toroidal-mode mantle flows competing and interfering with each other at different depths in the back-arc, fore-arc and sub-slab regions? (2) What are the effects of slab detachment and tearing on the circulation of mantle flows? (3) How do mantle flows respond as the slabs penetrate the 660-km discontinuity or flatten within the transition zone? Answering these questions will have implications for understanding subduction processes in different disciplines of Earth Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

por.por_cntn:
Analogy to ripples generated when you dive into water, the subduction of oceanic lithospheres will stir the ambient mantle and drive flows surrounding them. Mapping these flow circulation patterns has profound implications for understanding the dynamical, thermal and chemical evolution of subduction systems. Over the past several decades, by compiling global shear wave splitting measurements, and examining their correlations with a range of tectonic parameters, including trench migration speeds, plate convergence rates, slab ages, etc, seismologists proposed several conceptual model about the development of 2-D corner and 3-D return flows, driven by the downdip motion and rollback of subducting slabs. The geodynamic community has extensively investigated this model using laboratory experiments and mantle flow simulations. In addition, a number of shear wave splitting studies observed the trench-parallel pattern in the fore-arc and sub-slab regions, and the trench-perpendicular pattern in the back-arc regions. Unfortunately, due to the limited vertical resolution of shear wave splitting, until now, the depth variations of poloidal and toroidal mantle flows in real subduction zones remain poorly investigated in the seismology community. 

In this project, we build a 3D azimuthal anisotropy model for the North and Middle America by using waveform recorded collected by the USArray and other arrays. We find some intriguing features underneath the Middle American and Cascadia Subduction Systems. 

(1) The Middle American and Caribbean Subduction Zones are ideal locations to test the above conceptual model, because of their complicated subduction history, fast trench migration rates (around 20 to 40 mm per year), and diverse slab morphologies, including flat subduction, slab detachment and tearing, etc. In our model, a number of intriguing anisotropic features are observed, allowing us to characterize detailed 3-D mantle flow circulation patterns associated with the above two subduction zones. Major observations in this area include:

a. return flows warping around the narrow, fast rollback Rivera and advancing Atlantic slabs;

b. escape flows moving across slab windows underneath Panama and central Mexico;

c. underneath Nicaragua and Costa Rica, arc-parallel mantle flows are revealed at depths greater than 300 km in the sub-slab region, as well as at 50 km in the mantle wedge. In contrast, arc-perpendicular flow fields dominate the mantle wedge at depths greater than 50 km.

(2) The Cascadia Subduction Zone (CSZ) is also a unique place to study subduction-induced mantle flow, because of the following reasons:

a. the young (~25 Myr) Explorer, Juan de Fuca and Gorda Plates are actively subducting underneath the North American Plate;

b. there is a fast trench migration rate (~30 mm/yr);

c. unique shear wave splitting measurements have been documented, i.e., no trench-parallel pattern in the sub-slab and fore-arc regions;

d. controversial interpretations about the intriguing, circular shear wave splitting pattern in Nevada, including lithospheric drip, mantle plume and subduction-induced toroidal-mode mantle flow (Figure 1A);

e. diverse geochemical signatures observed in the Columbia River Flood Basalt, High-Lava Plains as well as the Snake River Plain. 

All these geophysical and geological features suggest the development of complicated mantle flows underneath the CSZ. Our major findings in this area include:

a. demonstrating the development of poloidal-mode mantle flows at shallow depths (<200 km) in the sub-slab and arc regions of the CSZ, in agreement with pervious onshore/offshore shear wave splitting measurements;

b. presenting seismic evidence for the development of two large-scale, toroidal-mode mantle flows at depths greater than 300 km, one surrounds the Juan de Fuca Plate underneath Idaho and Montana, and the other circulating around the lateral edge of the Gorda Plate. These observations support previous hypothesis about the development of toroidal-mode mantle flows in the western U.S. (Zandt and Humphreys, 2008, Geology);

c. a fast wavespeed body is revealed underneath the Wyoming Craton from the surface down to 400 km, which might reflect small-scale edge convection owing to the contact between the warm and active western U.S. with the thick and cold North American lithosphere. This feature is more prominent in comparison to the previously proposed lithospheric drip underneath Nevada and delamination underneath the Colorado Plateau. 

These findings will have significant implications for future studies on subduction systems and mantle circulation in many disciplines of Earth Sciences, such as providing independent constraints for future geodynamic flow simulations. In addition, the observed modest anisotropic strengths (1%) at depths greater than 400 km in model US32 challenge the current knowledge regarding the deformation mechanisms and anisotropic properties of minerals in the transition zone and lower mantle. Observations in our study provide additional evidence and more detailed features (mantle flow directions) to support one of their conclusions, i.e., the importance of dislocation creep in the deep Earth. 

This project allows the PI to support two PhD students, two female undergraduate interns and several high school students to participate seismology research related to deep Earth structure at UT Dallas.
